questions.text: Which of the following is not an enzyme-inducing Anti-Epileptic Drug?
questions.solution:
Levetiracetam is not an enzyme-inducing antiepileptic drug (AED). Unlike the other options, it does not significantly induce hepatic enzymes and therefore does not have the same potential for drug interactions related to enzyme induction.

  • Carbamazepine: An enzyme-inducing AED that increases the metabolism of other drugs.
  • Phenytoin: An enzyme-inducing AED that also enhances the metabolism of other drugs.
  • Phenobarbital: A barbiturate that induces hepatic enzymes, affecting the metabolism of many drugs.
  • Levetiracetam: Does not induce hepatic enzymes and is considered a safer option regarding drug interactions.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Enzyme-inducing AEDs (e.g. carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, primidone, oxcarbazepine and eslicarbazepine).
  • Non-enzyme-inducing AEDs (e.g. sodium valproate, levetiracetam, gabapentin, vigabatrin, tiagabine and pregabalin).

Reference: RCOG Green Top Guideline no. 68, Epilepsy in pregnancy

questions.text: A 30 year old woman was diagnosed with obstetric cholestasis in the 36th week of pregnancy. Her bile acids were severely deranged. The decision to deliver was taken & she delivered a healthy male newborn. Postnatally, LFTs should be deferred for at least how many days?
questions.solution:
After birth women should be offered follow-up to ensure that LFTs have  returned to normal.

  • In normal pregnancy, LFTs may increase in the first 10 days of the puerperium; in a pregnancy complicated by obstetric cholestasis, routine measurement of LFTs should be deferred beyond this time.
  • So, it is recommended to defer liver function tests for at least 10 days after delivery to allow time for any transient liver dysfunction related to obstetric cholestasis to resolve and to ensure more accurate results.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

LFT may be increases in first 10 days of perpeurium, so in case of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy,

LFT should be follow-up after 10 days

Reference: RCOG Green Top guideline no. 43, Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following Plasmodium species has a special predilection for placental sequestration?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium falciparum has a special predilection for placental sequestration. It does this by expressing specific adhesion molecules that allow infected red blood cells to adhere to placental tissue. This leads to complications during pregnancy, such as placental malaria, which can adversely affect both the mother and the fetus.

a. vivax: Primarily causes malaria in non-pregnant individuals and does not have a strong association with placental sequestration.

c. ovale: Similar to vivax, it does not significantly affect pregnancy and lacks the placental sequestration capability.

d. malariae: Generally causes milder malaria and is not associated with placental sequestration.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Malarial parasites, especially P. falciparum, have an affinity for the placenta.
  • The affinity of the malarial parasites for the placenta may be due to establishment of a new vascular system, which provides a safe haven away from the host-effector defense mechanism, permitting free and unhindered replication of the parasite.
  • This is especially true of P. falciparum, which has the capacity to sequester deep into tissues during schizogony and thereby escapes immune attack.

questions.text: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome is most commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
• Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a comparatively rare haematological abnormality that accompanies microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA), thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury (AKI).
  • Cases of pregnancy- associated atypical HUS are known to occur during the postpartum period.

Options:

a) First trimester

This is not the typical period for Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) to occur, as it is more commonly associated with later stages of pregnancy or the postnatal period.

b) Second trimester

While complications can arise in this trimester, HUS is not most commonly seen here.

c) Third trimester

HUS may occur during this period but is still not the most common time for its presentation.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome is most commonly observed in the postnatal period, often following an episode of diarrhea caused by enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, G1P0, is at 24 weeks of gestation and has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) during her previous pregnancy. She has no significant comorbidities and is currently asymptomatic. The obstetrician is considering anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolism during this pregnancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate anticoagulant for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Warfarin (OPTION A) is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects and potential harm to the fetus.
  • Unfractionated heparin (OPTION B) can be used, but it requires frequent monitoring and is less convenient for the patient.
  • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) OPTION C is the preferred choice during pregnancy due to its safety profile and efficacy in preventing thromboembolism.
  • Fondaparinux (OPTION D) has limited safety data in pregnancy, making it a less common choice

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Anticoagulation is initiated with either unfractionated heparin (UFH) or LMWH (Table 55-4).
  • Although either type is acceptable, most recommend one of the LMWHs because of better bioavailability, longer plasma half-life, more predictable response, reduce risks of osteoporosis and thrombocytopenia, and less frequent dosing.

questions.text: All of the following cardiac conditions are managed with restricted fluid regime during labour, except:
questions.solution:
• For women with critical aortic stenosis, intensive monitoring during labor is essential. Pulmonary artery catheterization may be helpful because of the narrow margin separating fluid overload from hypovolemia.

Options:

a) Mitral stenosis

In mitral stenosis, fluid overload can lead to pulmonary congestion, so a restricted fluid regimen is recommended.

b) Mitral insufficiency

In mitral insufficiency, similar concerns about fluid overload apply, and fluid restriction is typically advised.

c) Aortic regurgitation

Aortic regurgitation also warrants careful fluid management to avoid worsening the hemodynamic state, typically recommending some degree of restriction.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Women with aortic stenosis are dependent on adequate end-diastolic ventricular filling pressures to maintain cardiac output and systemic perfusion.
  • Abrupt drops in end-diastolic volume may result in hypotension, syncope, myocardial infarction, and sudden death.
  • In other conditions like MS,MR & AR, intravenous fluids should be administered in a controlled manner, restricted to not more than 75 ml/hr. This should keep the patient on the 'dry' side.

choices.text: The most common underlying defects are ASD, VSD, and persistent ductus arteriosus
Death usually is caused by left ventricular failure with cardiogenic shock
Eisenmenger syndrome is considered to be an absolute contraindication to pregnancy
Pulmonary vascular resistance exceeds systemic resistance and leads to concomitant right-to-left shunting

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Eisenmenger syndrome & pregnancy, except:
questions.solution:
In Eisenmenger syndrome, death is more commonly associated with complications from right ventricular failure and arrhythmias rather than left ventricular failure.

Options:

a) The most common underlying defects are ASD, VSD, and persistent ductus arteriosus.

This statement is true. Atrial septal defects (ASD), ventricular septal defects (VSD), and patent ductus arteriosus are indeed common congenital heart defects that can lead to Eisenmenger syndrome.

c) Eisenmenger syndrome is considered to be an absolute contraindication to pregnancy.

This statement is true. Due to the high risk of maternal and fetal morbidity and mortality, pregnancy is generally considered contraindicated in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome.

d) Pulmonary vascular resistance exceeds systemic resistance and leads to concomitant right-to-left shunting.

This statement is true. In Eisenmenger syndrome, elevated pulmonary vascular resistance leads to right-to-left shunting when the pressures in the pulmonary circulation exceed those in the systemic circulation.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Eisenmenger Syndrome describes secondary pulmonary hypertension that arises from any cardiac lesion.
  • The most common underlying defects are ASD, VSD, and persistent ductus arteriosus.
  • The syndrome develops when pulmonary vascular resistance exceeds systemic resistance and leads to concomitant right-to-left shunting.
  • Pregnant women with Eisenmenger syndrome tolerate hypotension poorly, and death usually is caused by right ventricular failure with cardiogenic shock.
  • Eisenmenger syndrome is considered to be an absolute contraindication to pregnancy (American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, 2019)

questions.text: A 24 year old G1P0 woman presents with breathlessness & palpitations at 26th week of gestation. ECHO was done & she is diagnosed to be suffering from Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy. What is the most common cause of sudden death in HOCM?
questions.solution:
Complex arrhythmias may progress to sudden death, which is the most frequent cause of death.

  • Right heart failure: While it can occur in heart disease, it is not the most common cause of sudden death in HOCM.
  • Left heart failure: Can lead to significant morbidity but is not the primary cause of sudden death in HOCM.
  • Thromboembolism: While thromboembolic events can occur, they are not the primary cause of sudden death in HOCM.
  • Diagnosis of HOCM is established by echocardiographic identification of a hypertrophied and nondilated left ventricle in the absence of other cardiovascular conditions.
  • Most affected women are asymptomatic, but dyspnea, anginal or atypical chest pain, syncope, and arrhythmias may develop.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is characterized by thickening of the heart muscle, particularly affecting the left ventricle.
  • The most common cause of sudden cardiac death in patients with HOCM is arrhythmia. This is due to the structural changes in the heart, which can lead to ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation, causing sudden cardiac arrest.

questions.text: Granulomatosis infantiseptica results due to fetal infection by which of the following microorganisms?
questions.solution:
Granulomatosis infantiseptica is a severe, often fatal condition in neonates characterized by the presence of granulomas in multiple organs, especially the liver and skin. It is primarily associated with Listeria monocytogenes, a bacterium that can cause serious infections in pregnant women and their fetuses.

  • Cytomegalovirus: Causes congenital infections but is not associated with granulomatosis infantiseptica.
  • Listeria monocytogenes: The causative agent of granulomatosis infantiseptica; it can be transmitted from mother to fetus, leading to severe complications.
  • Toxoplasma gondii: Can cause congenital infection but not specifically granulomatosis infantiseptica.
  • Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA): Typically causes skin and soft tissue infections and is not a known cause of granulomatosis infantiseptica.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Listeriosis during pregnancy may be asymptomatic or may cause a febrile illness that is confused with influenza, pyelonephritis, or meningitis.
  • A classic description of overwhelming fetal infection is that of disseminated microabscesses and granulomas known as granulomatosis infantiseptica.
  • Treatment with ampicillin plus gentamicin is usually recommended because of its synergism against Listeria species (Rouse, 2016). trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole can be given to penicillin-allergic women.
  • Maternal treatment in most cases is also effective for fetal infection . No vaccine is available.
  • Prevention is by washing raw vegetables, cooking all raw food.

questions.text: A 26 year old G3P2L2 woman presents at 16 weeks' gestation with excessive vaginal discharge & symptoms of UTI. Urine Routene microscopy & CS sent. A vaginal swab was sent for culture & NAAT, which yielded Chlamydia trachomatis. Which of the following drugs is first line for management of Chlamydial infections in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Currently recommended treatment regimens for chlamydial infections:

  • Azithromycin is first-line treatment in pregnancy.
  • The fluoroquinolones and doxycycline are usually avoided in pregnancy, and erythromycin estolate is contraindicated because of drug-related hepatotoxicity.

Options:

a) Fluoroquinolones

Fluoroquinolones are not recommended during pregnancy due to potential risks of cartilage damage and other adverse effects on the developing fetus.

b) Doxycycline

Doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters, due to the risk of staining of teeth and potential bone growth issues in the fetus.

c) Erythromycin estolate

While erythromycin can be used, it is not the first-line treatment. It has been used as an alternative for those allergic to azithromycin.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Azithromycin

This is the first-line treatment for chlamydial infections in pregnant women. It is safe, effective, and well-tolerated, with a single dose regimen that simplifies adherence.

questions.text: To prevent STI transmission, guidelines for expedited partner therapy (EPT) created by CDC recommend treatment to be provided to persons who were sexual contacts of the patient within the prior:
questions.solution:
• To prevent STI transmission, guidelines for expedited partner therapy (EPT) have been created by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and are endorsed by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
  • With EPT, treatment is provided to persons who were sexual contacts of the patient within the prior 60 days.
  • This approach helps reduce the risk of reinfection and further transmission of STIs.
  • Partner therapy may be a prescription slip for the partner, direct medication administration to the partner and patient simultaneously, or a medication packet delivered to the partner(s) by the patient.
  • Ideally, EPT does not replace traditional partner referral to allow their medical assessment, counselling, and screening for other STIs.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • With EPT, treatment is provided to persons who were sexual contacts of the patient within the prior 60 days.
  • The goal of EPT in pregnancy is to lower reinfection rates and adverse maternal and neonatal effects

choices.text: ART is recommended for all pregnant women with HIV infection
ART should be initiated as early in pregnancy as possible
Treatment reduces the risk of perinatal transmission regardless of CD4 T-cell count or HIV RNA level
ART regimens can be discontinued 6 months postpartum

questions.text: ART is recommended for all pregnant women with HIV infection
questions.solution:
ART regimens not be discontinued postpartum but continued lifelong for the advantages of viral suppression.

Options:

a) ART is recommended for all pregnant women with HIV infection

This statement is correct. Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is recommended for all pregnant women diagnosed with HIV to reduce the risk of transmission to the fetus and to maintain the mother's health.

b) ART should be initiated as early in pregnancy as possible

This statement is also correct. Early initiation of ART is crucial for maximizing the benefits of treatment and minimizing the risk of perinatal transmission.

c) Treatment reduces the risk of perinatal transmission regardless of CD4 T-cell count or HIV RNA level

This statement is correct. Effective ART significantly reduces the risk of perinatal transmission of HIV, regardless of the mother's CD4 count or viral load.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • ART is recommended for all pregnant women with HIV infection, and it should be initiated as early in pregnancy as possible.
  • Treatment reduces the risk of perinatal transmission regardless of CD4 T-cell count or HIV RNA level.

questions.text: A 26 year old G1P0 woman at 33 weeks' gestation is suffering from obstetric cholestasis. LFTs are being monitored. Which of the following biochemical markers can be directly correlated with adverse perinatal outcome?
questions.solution:
Obstetric cholestasis, also known as intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP), is a liver condition that can occur in late pregnancy. It is characterized by the slowing or stopping of bile flow, which leads to a build-up of bile acids in the liver and bloodstream. This can cause symptoms such as severe itching, particularly on the hands and feet, and sometimes jaundice.

The exact cause of obstetric cholestasis is not clear, but hormonal and genetic factors are believed to play a role. It is important to monitor and manage this condition to reduce the risk of complications for both the mother and the baby.

Treatment of Obstetric Cholestasis

  • Medication: Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) is commonly prescribed to relieve itching and reduce bile acid levels.
  • Vitamin K: This may be given to reduce the risk of bleeding, as bile acids are crucial for vitamin K absorption.
  • Early Delivery: In some cases, induction of labor might be recommended around 37-38 weeks to reduce the risk of complications for the baby.

Risks and Complications

  • Preterm Birth: Increased risk of preterm labor.
  • Fetal Distress: High bile acid levels can affect the baby.
  • Stillbirth: Although rare, there is a higher risk of stillbirth(if bile acid levels were >100 μmol/L.
  1. Aspartate transaminase levels: Elevated levels can indicate liver damage but do not have as strong a correlation with perinatal outcomes as serum bile acids.
  2. Gamma GT levels: While elevated in cholestasis, they are not as directly related to adverse outcomes as bile acids.
  3. Conjugated bilirubin levels: Can indicate liver function but are not as predictive of perinatal outcomes as serum bile acids.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • In obstetric cholestasis, elevated serum bile acid levels are the most significant biochemical marker directly correlated with adverse perinatal outcomes, including preterm labor, fetal distress, and stillbirth.

questions.text: A 21-year old primigravida presents at 9 weeks of gestation with severe nausea & vomiting since past 48 hours, failed to subside with oral medications. She is diagnosed with hyperemesis gravidarum and was advised to get admitted for fluid & electrolyte correction. She refused and a day later returned with confusion, ataxia & nystagmus. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Wernicke's encephalopathy is a rare reversible neurological complication of hyperemesis gravidarum due to vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency.
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum (HG) is associated with prolonged starvation and electrolyte imbalance leading to Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is a triad of ocular signs, ataxia, and confused mental state.

Options:

a) Cerebrovascular accident

While a cerebrovascular accident (stroke) can cause confusion and ataxia, it is less likely in a young pregnant woman without other risk factors. The acute onset of symptoms following severe vomiting points more towards Wernicke's.

b) Hyponatremia

Hyponatremia can cause confusion and neurological symptoms; however, it typically presents with additional signs such as seizures or altered mental status rather than the specific triad seen in Wernicke's encephalopathy.

c) Renal failure

Renal failure can lead to confusion and other neurological symptoms, but it is not the most likely cause in this scenario, especially given the context of hyperemesis gravidarum and the specific neurological symptoms presented.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Wernicke's encephalopathy is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which can occur due to prolonged vomiting and inadequate nutrition. The symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and nystagmus are characteristic of this condition.

Mnemonic: Signs & symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy can be remembered as

GOA -- Global confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Ataxia

questions.text: Most frequent presenting symptom of cerebral venous thrombosis in a pregnant woman is:
questions.solution:
• Thrombosis of the lateral or superior sagittal venous sinus usually occurs in the puerperium and often in association with preeclampsia, sepsis, or thrombophilia.
  • It is more common in patients with inherited thrombophilias or antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • Headache is the most frequent presenting symptom, neurological deficits are common, and up to a one third of women have seizures.
  • The diagnosis is made using MR venography.

Options:

a) Muscular weakness

While muscular weakness can occur in CVT, it is not as common a presenting symptom as headache. It typically arises later as the condition progresses.

b) Neurological deficit

Neurological deficits can manifest in cases of CVT, but they are not the most frequent initial symptom.

Symptoms like weakness or sensory loss may develop depending on the location of the thrombus. d) Seizures

Seizures can occur in CVT, but they are less common as an initial presenting symptom compared to headache. Seizures are more likely to develop as a result of increased intracranial pressure or direct involvement of cortical areas.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Headache is the most frequent presenting symptom of cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) in pregnant women. The headache can be severe and persistent, often resembling a migraine.
  • Management includes anticonvulsants for seizures, and anticoagulation with heparin.

questions.text: The fetus depends on maternal thyroid hormones until __ weeks of gestation:--
questions.solution:
• The fetus depends on maternal thyroid hormones until 12 weeks of gestation.
  • If pregnant women remain untreated, it increases the risk of miscarriage, fetal loss and low birth weight.
  • Reduced intelligence quotient (IQ) and neurodevelopmental delay have also been reported in the offspring of undertreated mothers (especially in the first and second trimesters).

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • The most common cause of hypothyroidism in pregnancy is Hashimoto thyroiditis, characterized by glandular destruction from autoantibodies, particularly anti-TPO antibodies.
  • The fetus depends on maternal thyroid hormones until 12 weeks of gestation.

choices.text: Usually presents within 1 year of childbirth
Etiology is generally unknown although it is attributed to having an autoimmune origin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about postpartum thyroiditis?
questions.solution:
Incidence of postpartum thyroiditis is more common in diabetics.

Options:

a) It affects 1% of women

This statement is generally true. Postpartum thyroiditis occurs in about 1-5% of women after childbirth.

b) Usually presents within 1 year of childbirth

This statement is also true. Postpartum thyroiditis typically manifests within the first year after delivery, often between 1 to 6 months postpartum.

c) Etiology is generally unknown although it is attributed to having an autoimmune origin This statement is true. While the exact cause of postpartum thyroiditis is not well understood, it is considered to have an autoimmune component, similar to other thyroid disorders.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

The incidence of postpartum thyroiditis is actually more common in women with diabetes due to shared autoimmune mechanisms.

choices.text: She needs to undergo visual field testing only in the third trimester
She needs to be subjected to regular CT/MRI
Serial serum prolactin levels are essential for diagnosis
Symptomatic tumor enlargement should be treated immediately with a dopamine antagonist such as bromocriptine or cabergoline

questions.text: A G2P1L1 8 weeks' pregnant woman with pre-existent pituitary macroadenoma (prolactinoma) is anxious regarding her course in pregnancy. What advice would you offer her as a treating doctor?
questions.solution:
• Pregnant women with macroadenomas should be followed closely and have visual field testing during each trimester. CT or MR imaging is recommended only if symptoms develop.
  • Serial serum prolactin levels are of little use because of normal increases during pregnancy.
  • Symptomatic tumor enlargement should be treated immediately with a dopamine antagonist such as bromocriptine or cabergoline.

Options:

a) She needs to undergo visual field testing only in the third trimester

This statement is incorrect. Regular visual field testing should be performed throughout the pregnancy, not just in the third trimester, to monitor for any changes due to the tumor.

b) She needs to be subjected to regular CT/MRI

This statement is also incorrect. Routine imaging such as CT or MRI is not typically performed during pregnancy due to the risks associated with radiation exposure. MRI can be used if clinically indicated but is usually avoided unless necessary.

c) Serial serum prolactin levels are essential for diagnosis

This statement is misleading. While monitoring prolactin levels can be useful, it is not the primary diagnostic tool for managing a macroadenoma during pregnancy.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Symptomatic tumor enlargement should be treated immediately with a dopamine antagonist such as bromocriptine or cabergoline.
    • This is crucial for managing symptoms related to tumor enlargement and ensuring the health and safety of both the mother and fetus.
  • Surgery is recommended for women with no response, including those with pituitary apoplexy

questions.text: Which type of left ventricular remodelling occurs in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
• In non-pregnant subjects with a normal heart who sustain a high-output state, the left ventricle undergoes longitudinal remodelling, and echocardiographic functional indices of its deformation provide normal values.
  • In pregnancy, there instead appears to be spherical remodelling, and these calculated indices that measure longitudinal deformation are depressed.
  • Thus, these normal indices are likely inaccurate when used to assess function in pregnant women because they do not take into account the spherical eccentric hypertrophy characteristic of normal pregnancy.

Options:

a) Longitudinal

This type of remodelling refers to changes in the length of the heart muscle fibers and is not typically associated with pregnancy-related changes.

b) Spherical concentric

This type describes a uniform thickening of the ventricular walls and a reduction in chamber size, which is not characteristic of the changes seen in pregnancy.

d) Spiral

This term is not commonly used to describe remodelling patterns of the heart and does not apply to the changes seen in pregnancy.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

In pregnancy, the left ventricle undergoes eccentric remodelling, characterized by an increase in chamber size with wall stress, often due to increased blood volume and cardiac output.

choices.text: Viral infections, especially BK virus, infections are frequent
GDM is found in approximately 25% cases
The incidence of rejection episodes approximates only 2 percent

questions.text: A 32-year old woman with a history of renal transplantation 2 years ago, becomes pregnant. All of the following statements are true for a pregnancy after renal transplantation, except:
questions.solution:
Gestational diabetes is found in approximately 5 percent cases of pregnancy after renal transplantation, largely due to immunosuppressive therapy. Rest all statements are true.

Options:

a)Viral infections, especially BK virus, infections are frequent

This statement is true. BK virus infections can be more common in individuals with renal transplants due to immunosuppression.

b) Incidence of preeclampsia increases

This statement is true. Women with a history of renal transplantation have a higher risk of developing preeclampsia during pregnancy.

c) GDM is found in approximately 25% cases

This statement is false. The incidence of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) is typically lower than 25% in pregnant women with renal transplants.

d) The incidence of rejection episodes approximates only 2 percent

This statement is true. The incidence of acute rejection episodes during pregnancy is relatively low, around 2-5%.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

While pregnant women with renal transplant do have increased risk of GDM. The incidence is generally lower than 25%, generally, 5%.
